ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! We learned about many things that families do together.
In this activity, you will take turns looking at picture cards and talk about what the families are doing together. Then you will try to identify who’s who in the family.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk-emphasis: Allow each child a chance to act out what is happening in one of the six picture cards.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show a picture card and ask children to describe what they see on the front of the card.
Guess Who’s Who Ask children to identify the different family members in each picture.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Have another child pick the next picture card. Continue until all of the picture cards have been used.

Talk About Family Activities Invite children to talk about what they saw on the picture cards. How many of these things do they do with their own families? Do they do them the same way? Who does them in a different way than the people on the card? Tell us how it is different.

For younger or developmentally delayed children, read aloud the Ask and Support sections on each card. Encourage children to use as many describing words as possible to say what they see the families doing in the pictures.
After discussing each picture card, ask children to talk about how the activity pictured on the card is different from the same activity that they might do with their own families.

Be sensitive to cultural variations that come up during this activity. Invite children to share special words from the languages they speak at home as they discuss different activities that their families do together.

Provide paper and crayons or other drawing materials. After looking at each card, have children draw a picture that shows their own family doing an activity. Children can describe their drawings to the class.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the book First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! We talked about how we use our imagination when we hear stories. We tried to imagine what it would be like to be those characters and do the things that they do.
Our imaginations help us make pictures in our minds of things that we’ve never seen or done. It’s fun to pretend that we are different than we are. It’s fun to use our imagination.
In this activity, we will look at pictures of different families. You will use your imagination to think about you and your family doing the same activity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show each picture card to the children. Ask the question on the back of the card. Offer extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Using Your Imagination Discuss with children different ways that they can use their imaginations. Where would they go and what would they do?

If children are having a hard time imagining what the families might be doing, ask them to describe what they see in the picture. Then invite children to use their imaginations to picture themselves in the family in the picture. Ask them what role they could play.
Have pairs work together to come up with stories about the families in the picture. They can create a story about the different members of this family. They can even give the family members names.
Give multilingual learners the option of acting out what the family in the picture is doing or is about to do. Children can draw their answers if they have a hard time explaining.

Have children draw what they see in one of the pictures. They can draw themselves in the scenario and talk about the role that they would play. Have children use crayons, markers, and other creative tools to decorate their drawings.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Write simple sentences about family members on sheets of paper. For example, My dad is special because ; My mom can ; I like spending time with my brother/sister because ; My grandparents told me about . Make copies. Staple these pages into a book with a cover that says My Special Family. Children can add or take out pages as necessary.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We read the book First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! and learned special things about a Navajo family. Let’s think of ways that our own families are special.
In this activity, we’ll make a book about our family members and show what makes them special. I’ll help you with the writing part.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Write/Design the Book Pass out the stapled pages you put together and go over each page with children, asking them to dictate the end of each sentence so you can write it in. Then have them use crayons or other art supplies to decorate the pages. You can do this activity over a number of days and send the books home so that children’s family members can help.
Make a Cover Invite children to decorate the cover of the book by drawing a group picture that shows all the family members they showed inside.

Share the Books Invite children to share their books with the other children and talk about what makes their families special. Have them show and discuss the artwork inside the book. Share the books with children’s family members at a family celebration.

Take note of children who seem to be having difficulty with this activity. Help children by providing cloze sentences for the prompts you provided, such as, My mom can dr
(draw) pictures.
Encourage peer-to-peer conversations about the special things their family members do together. Invite children to talk about the pictures they drew in their books.

Children may want to use words or phrases in their home language as they work on their books. Provide children with help, including translating any of their sentences into English so that their books can be in both languages. Point out that the authors of First Laugh—Welcome, Baby! included Navajo words in the book.

Children can use various art supplies to add more details to their family books. They can also bring in copies of photographs from home that they can cut up with your help in order to make family photo collages on the different pages.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we looked at the poster called My Family and Me. We learned about different people who can be part of a family.

In this activity, we’ll look at picture cards showing different groups of animals. We’ll talk about the animals we see and then sort the cards into two groups. We’ll decide if the picture belongs in the “Same Family” group or if it belongs in the “Not the Same Family” group.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Hand Signals Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows an animal family or a thumbs-down if it does not show a family. Model this before you begin.
Ask Ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to extend the conversation.
Sort Give the picture to a child to add to the “Same Family” or “Not the Same Family” group.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next picture card.

Talk About Families Invite children to talk about how they knew which picture cards showed animal families and which did not. Do they think real animal families have any of the same qualities as human families?
Talk About Favorite Animal Characters Can children name any books that are about animal families? Do children think these stories are true or make-believe? Why?

Show children two picture cards at a time, one that shows animals from the same family and one that does not. Ask, Which one of these pictures shows animals from the same family? Why? Repeat with other pairs of cards.
Create a chart called What Makes a Family? As you discuss how to sort the picture cards, ask children to help you come up with statements about families that you can add to the chart.

Review vocabulary related to families with the children. Presenting vocabulary thematically helps scaffold the language development of multilingual learners and encourages them to make word associations that they will remember. Make sure you use any new vocabulary words often in your discussions.

Have children make the sounds and movements of the animals they see on the picture cards. Ask volunteers to move their bodies like the animals would and make any sounds and gestures that show the things those animals might do to care for their babies.
